author: Shivani Vora
title: Homegrown wares delight shoppers in Zagreb's Lower Town
text:
High-quality hats with a classic aesthetic are the draw at Atelier Kobali, a more-than-a-century-old family enterprise. Matej Leskovsek for The New York Times by Shivani Vora Croatia's capital isn't typically thought of as a shopper's paradise, but the Lower Town of Zagreb is a favourite destination of in-the-know locals. It's a central area that developed in the early 20th century after the main train station, Zagreb Glavni Kolodvor, was built and is defined by its Hapsburg-era architecture, interconnected by garden squares. A robust collection of boutiques is scattered around pedestrian-heavy streets within a short walk from one another, and though their merchandise ranges widely, from handmade clothing and accessories to sweets and liqueur, most of the goods are made in Croatia.
Atelier Kobali
High-quality hats with a classic aesthetic are the draw at this more-than-a-century-old family enterprise. A small team of craftspeople constructs the headwear for men and women in material like wool, tweed, camel's hair and lace in a nearby workshop. Check out finds like the jaunty bright red wool beret for women and a men's light brown camel's hair top hat.
Petra Preradovica 1, Tel: +385-1-481-2867
Designer Nenad Sovilj, 35, creates one-of-a-kind jewelry, like an oversize resin bib-shaped necklace, with a turquoise spiked inlay and a black shoelace-like closure, and a spiked gold cocktail ring resembling a skyscraper. Prices from 400 kuna. Matej Leskovsek for The New York Take Me Home
Easy to miss at the end of a cobblestoned street, this small shop brims with eye-catching knickknacks like mugs, ceramics and stationery from local designers. Recent finds included square plastic key chains in a range of neon hues affixed with different robot patterns, cream sculptural-style beeswax candles and a bracelet of black onyx beads.
Tomiceva 4, Tel: +385-1-798-7632; takemehome.hr
Sovilj
 Easy to miss at the end of a cobblestoned street, Take Me Home brims with eye-catching knickknacks like mugs, ceramics and stationery from local designers. Matej Leskovsek for The New York Times This stylish shop with black-and-white monkey-patterned wallpaper is a showcase for the statement jewellery that the designer Nenad Sovilj, 35, creates in the tiny backroom. His attractive baubles are one-of-a-kind, like an oversize resin bib-shaped necklace, with a turquoise spiked inlay and a black shoelace-like closure, and a spiked faux-gold cocktail ring resembling a skyscraper.
Amruseva Ulica 5, Tel: +385-91-539-6031; sovilj.com
Croata
Part of an established Croatian chain specialising in ties for men and scarves for women, this spacious store offers hundreds of choices for each item. Though the broad range includes classic and trendier styles such as a slim maroon necktie dotted with Swarovski crystals and an orange silk scarf with a gold leaf border, they're all produced in small batches.
Ilica 5 (Oktogon), Tel: +385-1-645-7010; croata.hr
Natura Croatica
This tiny store packs in a gold mine of such Croatian delicacies as olive oil, sweets and liqueur. Though a highlight is the choice of 150 kinds of brandy – all available for sampling like a mixed herb from Gorski Kotar, a region west of Zagreb – the stock also has nine varieties of olive oil from Istria, almond and honey cake handmade on the island of Rab and sea salt from the Dalmatian Coast.
Petra Preradovica 8, Tel: +385-1-485-5076; naturacroatica.com
